abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            satisfactory, sustainability is likely, and the
            institutional development impact was substantial. Lessons
            suggest that sectoral reforms, cannot be entirely effective
            without the accompanying investments, needed to support the
            transition into a new policy environment. In addition,
            substantial delays in project start-up, and implementation
            can be avoided if institutional capabilities - technical,
            financial, and administrative - are properly assessed, and
            an agreed action plan formulated with the involved
            institutions for focused capacity building interventions.
            Additionally, there is the need for communal responsibility
            in promoting sustainable natural resources management, as
            well as the critical need of community organization, to
            focus on building partnerships at the local levels.
            Communities need to be fully engaged in the process, and
            with proper capacity building measures to sustain their
            needs. Formal long-term tenurial agreements for the
            utilization of State lands, provide concrete incentives for
            farmers, and upland settlers to invest time, and capital, in
            ensuring high standards of land management. However, funds
            transfer mechanisms need to be set, for channeling national,
            and donor financial resources to the local government units,
            during the transition stage, prior to their full
            decentralization. Enforced legislation would curb
            environmental degradation, and deforestation.
